name: Waring's problem
rephrased: For any whole number exponent k, there exists some number s such that every natural number can be written as the sum of at most s perfect kth powers.
implication_form: If k is a positive integer, then there exists a positive integer s such that every natural number is the sum of at most s kth powers.
explained: Waring's conjecture (now known as Waring's problem) states that for every integer power k â‰¥ 2, there exists a corresponding positive integer s (often denoted as g(k)) such that every natural number can be expressed as the sum of at most s perfect kth powers. In other words, for each k, there is a number s(k) such that the set of natural numbers is the union of s(k) copies of the set of kth powers of natural numbers.
related_conjectures: The four squares conjecture (a specific case for k=2)
The problem for cubes (k=3) and higher powers
